												BAD Pc Port of a Decent Game...Double Agent is probably my least favorite Splinter Cell game so far (comparing it to 1, Pandora Tomorrow, and Chaos Theory). Still, it is a good game if you can find a way to avoid all the game crashes and glitches. It's too bad the pc port is so terrible. It took me a while to figure out that you have to have your movespeed set to 2 mouse-wheel ticks higher than the lowest in order to open a safe. Otherwise, the sensitivity is REAL high. If I look past the port problems, there is a good game here. The missions provide decent environment variety. They added in a double-agent objective mechanic where you can choose what objectives to complete. Your decisions affect your trust with the Agency and the Terrorists. This is probably the most stealth-heavy title in the series so far, but it doesn't feel satisfying. Chaos Theory felt a lot better. The visuals also look worse than Chaos Theory for some reason.Unfortunately, I don't think I will finish this game. I decided to quit halfway through because of all the game crashes and the inability to disable intro videos.

												I've had my fair share of bad ports on PC, however this one is... well, I can't even describe how bad it is. Let's start at the beginning. While the previous game of the franchise - Chaos Theory (yes, yes, one of the BEST stealth game of all time, however I won't go into further detail now) - got an update (1.05) to run in widescreen resolution (up to 1920*1200), this game did not, so you have to do some .ini tweaking to get the desired one. Since we're at tweaking, there are couple of options in the .ini which aren't even present in game (for tweaking and issue resolving I recommend this page: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Splinter_Cell:_Double_Agent ). Even after you've done everything in your power to make the game a bit better, the shadows frequently flicker or just outright don't appear.Then comes the sound: sometimes after loading the game, the game won't display a huge number of sounds (but you can still hear Sam's breathing, steps and muffled/glitched gun shots).Then comes the loading issue: the save system is abysmal, you have 3 spaces to choose which one you'd like to load from / save to, you can't rename your save files (maybe you can, but I got so frustrated with the menu that I'd rather used the quicksave/load option) and sometimes quicksaves just outright disappeared. This usually happened when the game crashed, I reloaded my game using the "Continue" option which did load the quicksave file, however after wanting the quickload said file, I couldn't. What?!I've written about the menu and how bad it is, but why you ask? Sometimes you can't navigate it with the keyboard (moreover it defaults to WASD rather then the arrow keys, but whatever), the mouse is janky and you can't use your mousewheel while browsing your save game files.The OPSAT (Sam's ~infobar on his wrist during the game) is also equally bad, has all the problems just mentioned."Okay okay, but how's the game play?" You might ask. Well I could have gotten over all of the above, if only it was good or at least not as bad as I've come to know it. One word: awful. The controls are sometimes unresponsive, Sam just doesn't want to grab that ledge or crawl into a ventilation system no matter hard you try (like he's also fed up with the whole game "Nope, not gonna do it"). More often than not you get stuck on some random object which can also lead you being discovered or just missing your chance.I might have missed some issues because there's plenty and I didn't write any of it down, all of this is just off the top of my head. A real shame though because it was a great idea executed so poorly...So the question is: would I *recommend* the game? NO. If you like Splinter Cell, just skip it, if you're a "hardcore" SC fan, then you might, only might, want to give it a shot.

												[4/10]    As much as I'd love to finish this game, I don't think it will even let me. The game crashes almost every mission for no reason, quick saves will randomly decide to not load, the entire game just freezes during certain loading screens. Also, the game looks awful compared to previous games in the Splinter Cell franchise, which is odd, considering Chaos Theory was absolutely gorgeous for its time, and still holds up to this day. Sometimes shadows won't even render when the level loads, making the whole stealth mechanic extremely awkward. Being a huge fan of Splinter Cell, it's really unfortunate that this game is unstable, to the point of freezing my computer. I could only recommend this game to hardcore fans of the Splinter Cell franchise. I will attempt to finish this game, and if it gets better, I will edit this review. Until then, this still stands.[EDIT]So I've finished the game. The bugs and glitches are still present, no suprise there, but there was one specific bug that stood out amongst others: a game breaking bug. After completing the final mission, a cutscene is supposed to play, the credits should roll, and you are rewarded with a bonus mission. For me, and many others, this didn't happen. The mission would end, and then cut immediately to an overhead scene of the level where you are unable to move and unable to quit properly. (you have to enter the Task Manager and end it manually.) Aside from the awful technical issues, the gameplay and story are some of the best in the Splinter Cell series so far. It takes place shortly after the events of Chaos Theory, in which Sam must pose as a criminal and join a terrorist force in order to destroy them from the inside. The game has a "trust meter," in which you have to complete objectives for the JBA: the terrorist force, and the NSA: the good guys. Due to trust being a factor, the game forces you to enter in these moral gray areas just to keep the trust of the enemy. While in the base, you have the option to research and spy on your allies/enemies to learn more info about them. This information will assist you in traversing the base as well as unlock special items for your missions. As with all previous games in the franchise, it is all based on stealth and using gadgets as well as the enviornment to your advantage to accomplish your objectives. If you've played a SC game in the past, you know what you're getting yourself into from a gameplay perspective. Summary: Splinter Cell: Double Agent is a fantastic game form a gameplay and story perspecrive, but it is hindered by so many techinical issues that it is not worth the purchase, at least not on the PC. I have heard that the concole version is much better, so if you would like to play this game, play it on the Xbox, PS2, or PS3.

												Summed Up: A really awful port to an otherwise pretty fun game. Buy this game on any other platform and you'll have a fun time, but avoid the PC version like the devil.In-Depth: I'll start with the game itself. It's not going to be anyones favourite Splinter Cell as, quite frankly, it's one of the more linear and demanding of the series. Gone is the option to play the game your way and still get the best score if you complete the objectives; now the game ranks you on stealth. It provides penalties to how many guards you knock out/kill, locks you break etc. Meaning you have to basically be a shadow to get the best score. This is a fair idea, but the problem is, the level often throws enemies at you you HAVE to move out the way, or you have to do something ridiculously convoluted to get them to move; which just takes up way too much time.Also introduced is the trust system; a fine line you have to take between both the terrorists and your employers. Alot of people were kind of iffy on this, but I honestly liked the idea. The main issue stems from the fact it's completely pointless. There are enough side objectives and such that you'll honestly always have full trusts 99.9% of the time; even on hard mode where you lose trust more and gain less. If they had made it much more imperitive to the game and maybe had it so you gained rewards from having certain levels, or even something as simple as dialogue change, it might have been  a worthy addition. As it stands, it's just kind of there; a nice idea that dosen't realise it's full potential. As for the core game, it's pretty much Chaos Theoy's mechanics again. This is fine as, in my opion, Chaos Theory really got it right when it came to the stealth aspect and design; n both games have a nice, easy to navigate ingame inventory, the layouts easy to see etc. One major gripe thought is that they changed the stealth meters; as in, they no longer exist. In Chaos Theory, they had two bars which showed your visibility and sound. This was useful as it indicated how alert enemies where sound wise and indicated clearly how sneaky you were being. In this game, you have a light, that's it. It's green when your safe, yellow when not, and red when spotted. The problem is, while it takes into account shadows and does change when enemies are more alert, it never shows how much noise your making; which can be a HUGE problem if your next to an alerted enemy and want to sneak past him QUIETLY. But, that aside, it is for all intents and purposes just more of Chaos Theory sanded down. Back handed as that is, I'm not complaining at  a few more levels.Now for the crux of the problem; the PC Port. The best summary would be 'A glitched up mess that everytime I play I find another'. The most common one is random crashes and lost autosaves, but there are weirder ones. Lost sound, not gaining your bonus equipment, a door not supposed to be there stuck in another door (Yes, that actually happened), do I need to go on? Not to mention graphically, the game just looks off. There is a guide to tweak this on steam, but the fact you HAVE to do this is pretty appaling; without the tweaks, the game looks... well, off, it's hard to explain, kinda like the world is slowly falling away pixel by pixel in the background. There are alot of things in this port that just make it dissapointing, and I really tried to look past them. But the bugs really were the final straw. Avoid the port like the devil, patches have been known to exist, but wether they work is apparently 50/50. Go buy another version of the game elsewhere; you'll be glad you did

												I've played through Double Agent on DVD shortly after it was released on PC. Somewhere near the end of the game (in one of the Kinsasha-missons), I got stuck. Everytime I tried to load a safe, I would spawn under the map, resulting in Game Over. When I recently discovered Double Agent on Steam, I picked it up. I was hoping that they fixed at least some of the bugs and I would finally be able to play through the story. Unfortunately, I was wrong.The engine is very buggy. Sometimes there's no sound, sometimes you get stuck. Many times, the game will crash when saving or loading. Saves are very unreliable: they either disappear or just don't work.The stealth isn't great. The levels are rarely dark. The sound- and lightmeter of the previous game(s) are replaced by a big light on Sam's back. That light indicates if you're hidden, not hidden, or spotted. It doesn't always work: often you're supposedly hidden, but a guy at the other side of the map can still spot you. Sometimes you're not hidden, but there's a huge snowstorm going on and a guy on the other side of the level still raises the alarm. Especially on "Hard"-difficulty, not getting spotted is VERY strict.The interface is ported almost straight from the console-version. The inventory and interactions are kinda slow to use, as you have to cycle through them. There is no way to bind different weapons or gadgets to keys on your keyboard. You can't just plug in a controller to play this game. One positive note: you can use the Steam Controller set to KB/M-bindings. That works pretty well. The options in the menu are very limited. You can select "Normal" or "Next-Gen" graphics, and resolutions up to 1600x1200 pixels. Not all keybindings can be changed. The list of saves is very short, so you have to scroll a lot (and as mentioned before, the saves often don't work).There are some good things about this game, too. The story is arguably the best part of this game. The undercover-aspect is a fresh approach which works well enough. There are some very interesting locations, and they often look well (for their age). And finally, it is more Splinter Cell.If you are a die-hard Splinter Cell-fan, you might be interested to pick this up. But be warned that the experience might be troubled by technical difficulties or can be plain frustrating. If you're new to series or only a casual fan, check out the other games like Chaos Theory of Blacklist.=====TL;DR=====+ Story+ Locations+ Undercover+ Splinter Cell- Interface for controllers- No support for controllers- Unreliable saving / loading- Very limited menus- Many crashes- Many bugs- Average stealth:* It's barely dark* Enemies are super sensitiveConclusion: Double Agent is a very bad port which suffers from many bugs and is often frustrating. Only get if you're a very big Splinter Cell-fan.

(Online Servers are Shutdown)You choose the Pro's and Con's here becuase some people may argue about which is a pro and con and which is'nt.Summery Review: Splinter Cell Double Agent is a Third Person Action Stealth Shooter Released in 2006 as part of the Splinter Cell Series by Ubisoft and Tom Clancy. Splinter Cell Double Agent has alot of improvements from the previous title Splinter Cell Chaos Theory. The first really big Noticable Change from the previous title Chaos Theory is the graphic's. Splinter Cell Double Agents Graphics when it first released were updated from Chaos Theory but games grow old and with age comes with updates. Several of said updates added significant improvements to graphic's and added more options than before. Some other changes include new animations being added, more stability for modern system as well as compability for out-of-date systems (If your computer really is that old). Next thing players are gonna notice right off the bat when first playing Double agent is the length and difficulty of the missions. Double Agent Contains many things that no other splinter cell has one of them being the extreme length of the mission. These missions can be very comparable to the missions we seen in the original splinter cell and may take 40+ minutes to finish. The AI has gotten Tougher in this title and I found it hard to complete missions and playing on the hardest difficulty seemed nearly impossilbe due to the AI's ability to seemlessly shoot you through the wall but that is made but for by it's "Call of duty Style" 1-3 Shots results in the player dying. The game will get you through about 11 hours of total gameplay before beating the story I have owned this game for years and always find myself going back and restarting the game just to find that one area I never discovered or could never get into because it always seemed near impossible to get into without getting killed or detected. Replayability is also fun to find those computers that you may have missed or forgotten about with some splinter cell lore contained. One thing Splinter Cell Double Agent Introduced to the splinter cell Series in Unlockables. Unlockables in splinter cell double agent is obtained by completing "Star Objectives" which are usually optional objective but completeing them unlocks equipment that give the player an advantage in there undercover black operations within john brown's Army" Splinter Cell double Agent did include a CO-OP Mode with a Seperate story portrayed by the two characters from the previous splinter cell co-op Story mode but the servers were shutdown and the mode is no longer available. There is a feature in this game exclusive to double agent allowing the player to make story effecting decision's. Such Decisions will effect the Trust Meter between the NSA and the JBA. If the player allows one of these meters to expire the mission fails immediately until the player increases the expired meter. During the Beginning of the Story another Double Agent Exclusive Feature is found in the game which is Snowy enviroments. During the Beginning of the game Sam is given his "First Real Test" mission by the JBA and is taked with hijacking a supertanker Somewhere within Northern Russia and the Entire Mission is a Snow Enviroment where the player has to navigate through a blizzard and a white out which can be very difficult even when using the Goggles. Continuing on with the double agent exclusive feature, Underwater enviroments and combat. In Splinter Cell Double Agent we find a feature that is not in any other splinter cell that allows the player to swim around in water and submerge under. During the Mission to Hijack the Supertanker and the Very First mission in Island the player has the ability to surface but will be blocked by frozen water and has to cut through it to reach the surface. If there is an enemy on the ice above the player, the player has the ability to grab through the ice and pull there victim under and stab them to death. If the Victim is on an ajacent Shore by the frozen water or unfrozen even, the player also has the ability to take care of them this by pulling them off the shore and under the water.Conclusion: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell is a pretty dated game from the Early 2000's but The game introduced alot of feature we see in Splinter Cell Conviction and Blacklist. Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Contains many things only seen in Double Agent that I would like to see in future splinter cell titles. The Game has excellent graphics for its age. The difficulty for this game is a bit much when going into the hardest difficulty settings due to the AI being able to shoot through the walls at the player. I recommend this game I think its an excellent title and I think it brought us some great features that we see in modern titles and future titles. Some Exclusive Features such as the ability to use water as cover and a means of killing your enemy id like to see in future titles. I had alot of fun beating it years ago and still do today.

It makes the missions more tense as you get multiple objective from both factions (often conflicting with each other) and you have to choose on fly which ones you can afford to skip. This system also rewards skilled players. My favourite part of the game ere the semi-sandbox levels which take place in terrorist hideout. 												Some games do not age well. And Splinter Cell: Double agent is a great example of that. There is a lot of things wrong with the game and not many that were done right. I finished the game but there were times I thought about not trying to.Lets start with bad then shall we.The game crashes. And it crashes a lot. And there is no pattern just when will it crash. Sometimes in the middle of the mission, sometimes on mission load, sometimes on intro or outro of the mission. And sometimes it works just fine for an hour or longer. But on other times crashes after ten or fifteen minutes. Quite annoying. And once you decide to exit game, it can freeze itself forcing you to restart the windows in order to regain control.The graphics are aged and it shows. Fact that highest resolution is 1600x900 does not help either. To top that the first mission is really ugly which makes matters even worse at first. You get used to it later on and it's not that bad as the first impression.Audio seems fine most of times. Though lack of subtitles is extremely annoying. This was almost a reason not to play the game. The game does not introduce itself very well. It lacks that modern tutorial/guide style so present everywhere. This is somewhat refreshing but leaves a lot for player to figure out. Some things I've learned on almost ending missions. But the lack of waypoints saying exactly where to go was a bit of back to the roots trip. When you actually had to figure stuff out instead of going after the flashing blip. The story is rather bland. The start of it a disaster I would say. It gets a bit better later on but it is not to original or interesting at that. Mechanically it's not too good as well. The three vision mode, night, head and electronics are pretty much useless. I don't think I used them even once in a meaningful way. Shooting and combat are bad. Most annoying thing being - why the hell is a pistol more accurate than a rifle? I mean really. Grenades are useless as well.As a stealth game it fares much better. Sneaking is satisfying as much as stabbing the guys in the back. Most of the missions can be completed by remaining stealthy which is nice. Safe cracking is a nightmare though. The controls for it are terrible.That should be about time to tell something good about the game. So what it does going for it are pretty well designed levels and missions. They're interesting and challenging. Some of them are approachable by different ways I guess though it's not the same amount of freedom as Hitman games for example. Also the JMB headquarter levels are very nice - especially with the trust mechanic. This is the only part that makes the game worth playing. Time you are given to complete some additional objectives really adds to the double agent atmosphere.Overall I'd say 6/10 if you disregard the crashes. Not really something I can wholeheartedly recommend though I've played worse games.

												***Anti-recommendation.***This is an incredibly bad port of the XBox360/PS3/Wii (Current-Gen) version and is riddled with unpatched bugs. Between this and the XBox/PS2/GameCube (Last-Gen) version with the same name, the Last-Gen version is better than the Current-Gen version by leaps and bounds.Stealth, once a delicate management of light and sound, has been dumbed down to a traffic light indicator of "he probably can or can't see you."The iconic night/thermal vision goggles which once defined this series have been rendered useless. The thermal mode has an effective radius of about 5 feet and can no longer see though thin doors or curtains. Night vision is little more than a pointless green filter which hardly gets any use due to the large number of daytime missions. For the most part, you'll just rely on your Soliton radar, anyway.Cutscenes used in both versions of this game are completely devoid of the context provided by the Last-Gen story and feel more or less shoehorned into the Current-Gen version. Subsequently, the entire set-up for the sequel, SC:Conviction, is barely even hinted at. The Last-Gen version, by contrast, made the character motivations for the sequel hook abundantly clear.If you want the stealth-based gameplay of the classic Splinter Cell, pick up the original or Chaos Theory. For the modern, Uncharted-style cover-based action shooter, just skip straight to Conviction.Avoid the Current-Gen version of Double Agent at all costs. Save yourself the trouble and just watch the Let's Play of both versions of this game on YouTube.

												I loved Chaos Theory like a brother, but this might be the worst game I've ever played.It's not just the glitches and the crashes. Alpha Protocol was buggy (though not as buggy as this), but I still love that game. I can get past a few bugs, but this game was broken from its inception. It's muddled in terrible, dumbed-down, counter-intuitive design. It's an insult to the brilliant design in the previous three. The horrible PC port was just the icing on the cake.The first three games were reasonably paced, and emphasized a reliance on light and sound. If you were going to complete your mission, you needed to be a master of the shadows. In Double Agent, they dial it back to the lowest common denominator, and just make you hide behind conveniently placed objects. They try to pretend that light still plays a factor with a little yellow light on the back of your suit, but even when the light says you're concealed, enemies can still spot you from miles away. Direct concealment, and exploitation of predictable patrol patterns, is your only option out in the field.But it's out of the field where it really hits the fan. In the JBA headquarters, Sam is tasked with skulking around the base and completing tasks for both the NSA and JBA, but doing so requires mastery of one of the worst level layouts in history. If you remember that 3D map that you never used in Chaos Theory, just because it worked so poorly that the game was easier to navigate without it, you'd be happy to know that it makes a triumphant return in Double Agent. Prepare to squint like your life depended on it, as you try to make heads or tails of all the different branching paths that lead to dead ends, and plot a precise route to your objective, only to be sent back to the drawing board when you come across a secuity door, and need to plot a new route to whatever grand McGuffin will unlock it. None of this is even challenging at all, it's just unbelievably tedious.And that's my biggest problem with this game. It's so lazy, so insecure in its ability to give you a single, satisfying experience, that it just piles on busywork and hopes that'll keep you satiated. I do not play Splinter Cell to navigate through a cartoonish series of security doors, I play it for a challenging, satisfying stealth game. Double Agent is the complete opposite of everything the original three games stood for, and as a result, has none of what made them fun or interesting.It's a horrible game even if you forgive the bugs, but they're still well worth mentioning. The game crashes during every mission, mandatory safe-cracking minigames don't function in any capacity, the frame rate dips and the graphics glitch out even on systems well above the system requirements, one snow mission near the beginning will run for maybe five seconds before giving you a BSOD, and some events will flat-out fail to trigger.The first three Splinter Cell games had none of these problems (with the exception of a buggy shadow engine in Pandora Tomorrow, and one scripting bug in that same game that made me restart a level), and Chaos Theory somehow even had better graphics. Double Agent has no excuse. It's just a terrible game on every level.The only thing this game has that's even remotely interesting is its morality system, and it's bare-bones at best. It's not a moral dilemma if the numbers on your screen clearely dictate what's the right choice. You aren't making hard decisions, you're just balancing stat bars, and like all the other busywork in this game, that isn't any fun. I know I already mentioned this game, but Alpha Protocol had a far better idea of what espionage morality entailed, on top of just being better, more inspired, more fun, and more functional than this game on every count.Even for the more hardcore Splinter Cell fans, I wouldn't recommend this game. It's just horrible.

												This is so bizarre.  I remember having this game on Playstation 2 back in the day and having fond memories of it and yet people keep saying this is not nearly as good as Chaos Theory.  While Chaos Theory is amazing I recall Double Agent having most of the same mechanics and an interesting undercover element.  So I install it to give it one more playthrough only to see what everyone was fussing about.  This is NOT the game I played on PS2.  Not by a long shot.  The missions are all different.  The story, the gameplay... Everything dumbed down.  As a long time fan of this series I was always confused by how so many people said this wasn't a good game.  Now I see why.  PC Double Agent is a very different animal to the console Double Agent in every way.  All the things I liked about the PS2 version is not here.  I enjoyed this game but despite its flaws and unlike all the other Splinter Cell games I have no desire to ever touch this one again.  The biggest problem was just how hard it was to avoid being spotted.  Like when you thought you were well hiddent and it turns out you weren't and there's no chance seeing it coming.  Enemies can spot you miles away and will shoot you instantly with pinpoint accuracy.  Sometimes through walls.  The undercover aspect between missions where you sneak around the terrorists base to do things during a time limit has been significantly dumbed down as well.  Oh get spotted in a restricted area "Fisher you're not supposed to be here" with a little bump in trust.  I rememebr the stakes being much higher on PS2 with them shooting you on sight and better level design as well.  There just doesn't seem to be any tension in the stealth.   You either succesffully sneak through or you dont.  Half the time I would just go around a corner after being spotted and wait for the alert to go away after a second and its like nothing happened.  Oh noes my stealth score goes down?  I can't unlock gear that I'll never need?  pFFFFt say what you will about Conviction and Blacklist being more action oriented but at least those game's mechanics work well.Edit: I didn't even talk about the crappy interface and other issues that plague this game.  When spacebar is your action button for everything from opening doors to turning light switches to grabbing guards from behind it makes sense to have a prompt on screen to let you know exactly what you're about to do.  All the games before this had it simply say it at the bottom of the screen.  Here its shoved in your face in the middle of the screen as if to say "YOU'RE ABOUT TO DO A THING JUST TO MAKE SURE YOU HAVE ADD AND CAN'T TELL"  As if thats not bad enough you can't use your mouse while hacking computers or reading emails.  You can't even type in the numbers when using a keypad lock!  Sometimes while opening safes it doesn't register the keys until you play with the mouse wheel for some reason.  Top it all off with glitches such as bodies flying away after you drop them completely destroying your efforts of hiding them.  On a couple occasions they just flopped around for minutes until enemies nearby noticed and i was screwed.  This doesn't even touch on the save issues when it doesn't read its own auto saves or in one mission reoloading a save causes the game to crash.  Its all these little problems littered throughought the game that just made it more of a hassle.  I mean Chaos Theory (the game before this) had gamepad support!  It didn't work very well.  It didn't register R2 and L2 on a PS3 controller but it was there.  This one has none.  Doesn't read the controller at all... How do you have so many downgrades?  Its so counter-intuitive to PC gaming when even the first Splinter Cell was more intuitive than this!!!!This is the only game in the series where I will say skip it.  If you can get an old copy of a console version in a bargain bin somewhere go for that.  That version is far superior to this extreme change for no reason.  Makes no sense why they made two completely different games for different platforms.  For all I know the Xbox version is even more different so I would play it safe and just find a PS2 if you must play every game in the series.

												Broken Cell Double AgentAfter owning the first Splinter Cell for years but never finished it. I then bought the first 3 Splinter Cells on PC and finished all three of them a couple of years ago. Each one was fantastic though I felt that the shadows in Pandora Tomorrow were a little off but otherwise good. The game that stood out of the three however was Chaos Theory with hardly anything to critise about it. It had brilliant stealth mechanics, a great soundtrack, great level design, good story, supposedly good co-op (haven't played it) and of course the legendary spies vs mercs mode.After three amazing titles, you would expect the 4th installment of the series to be able to live up to its predecessors right? Wrong!This game makes me rage in so many ways! The game feels rushed and unfished, the first game had good stealth mechanics, it beats this in terms of stealth mechanics by far which means that this isn't just a step back, this is a few jumps backwards. There are rarely any proper shadows in this which means that the only way you can tell if you're invisible is by looking at the indicator either on your back or in the bottom left hand corner of your screen; if it is green you're invisible, if it's yellow, you are visible and are at risk of being detected and if you are red then you better run mofo because you're about to get your backside handed to you.This sounds like an okay system and may have been more acceptable had the light metres in the previous games never existed, but the problem with it is that the shadows aren't dark enough most of the time like they were in the previous titles which makes running into the shadows game of chance as either it will hide you or it won't, it's not obvious when you're about to enter an invisible area and because of this, I was constantly being detected in absolutely rediculous ways which was not fun at all and because of this I was constantly autosaving way more than I would of needed to in the earlier splinter cells, I think on average I autosaved about 55 times per level.The story however is actually good and I did enjoy it, what this game does offer that the previous titles did not were the ability to make choices in the game and making those choices would result in different outcomes which would give the game more replay value if the gameplay wasn't so bad.But one of the biggest problems I have with the game is it's incredibly bad PC port, it is so sloppy despite it being the same version of the game as the xbox 360 and the PS3. Why is it so bad? it crashes constantly for no reason and I have quite a high spec 3 month old pc and this is 2014, the game is so badly optimised and it is absolutely outrageous that ubisoft haven't fixed it, I'd hate to think what would happen if I were to run this on my old computer with 10 year old hardware.The menu system in the game is annoying and every time you want to hack into a computer or look under a door, you have to watch this stupid animation on your opsat which lasts 3 seconds, that might not sound that bad but when you have to watch it so regularly and it's the same animation over and over again it really gets frustrating.I've also heard that Spies Vs Mercs was completely ruined in double agent which is just another reason not to like the game so just throwing that out there.Oh, and every time you either want to hack a safe or the mine assembly (both of which are annoying events that you have to do), make sure that you are in running mode as the game was so badly ported from console that when you try and do this whilst in walking mode, your controls to crack the safe or assemble the mines will simply not work.The only thing I can praise about the game are it's graphics and it's story oh and about that! I finished the last level last night and it loaded a cutscene in game, but the AI kept getting stuck on one of the textures which means that the cutscene was just stuck and my camera was stuck on the guy who was stuck and kept clipping through the catwalk so basically, I couldn't actually finish the game properly and so I had to look up the endings on youtube, absolutely redicolous given how old this game is now!One other thing I forgot to mention is that for the JBA which is the organisation you're working for but are actually a double agent, you have to visit and carry out objectives within their safehouse 4 times! 4 times! That's just repetitive and it's confusing trying to get to know your way around it especially for the final level seeing as the map on your opsat is just plain awful.So all in all, this game is worth playing I believe, but not on PC. Get Double Agent Version 1 on Xbox 360 or PS3 but not PC, it is just too buggy and it will annoy the hell out of you otherwise!One final note, there are actually two versions of Double agent, version 1 is on Xbox 360, PS3 and PC and version 2 is on Xbox, PS2, gamecube and wii. Version two was done by Ubisoft Montreal and as a result, I've been told that version 2 is much much better than version 1 and it is a completely different game with a completely different level layout even though they share the same name, apparently it feels more like Chaos Theory so I can't wait to check that out at some point.The bugs in this game make it unacceptable and it is a dissapointment given how great the last splinter cell was, only thing that holds it up are the graphics, the story, voice acting and I guess the level design.All in all, this game gets a 4/10 for me on PC as even though the story was very good, the gameplay was littered with bugs, bad stealth mechanics and felt nothing like its predecessors.

												This is probably the buggiest game I've ever played. I generally don't write reviews, but I wanted to compile a list of the issues I've faced, along with some advice.Before anything you should get the 1.02a patch from here : http://patches.ubi.com/splinter_cell_double_agent/splinter_cell_double_agent_1_02a.exeThis patch is not included in the steam version and already fixes some issues.1) It will crash. There's no real way around it. It WILL crash. However, 99% of all crashes happen during loading, so once a loading is done you shouldn't get too many crashes (I've had one or two in my entire playthrough). The crashes are extremely random, and to get past them you need to try loading a save multiple times, until it finally succeeds. If you look up how to resolve this problem, you might find people saying that you need to launch the game with a '-ll' option. This is useless and only made the game crash a bit faster for me. Sometimes adding '/safemode' to the game's launch command seemed to get around some persistant crashes (although it could be a simple coincidence). To do this, simply right-click on the game in your steam game list, select 'properties', and click 'set launch options'. There you can add or remove '/safemode'.At the very begining of the game I had a crash a few seconds after loading a game, which was solved when I tried using a third party patch to fix widescreen support (http://thirteenag.github.io/wfp#splintercell). Again, this might be a coincidence.2) I strongly advise against trying Windows' compatibility mode. I tried it and it only made the game start dropping some FPS' every few seconds.3) In some areas in the game you can get stuck (especially when you are crouching). To avoid trouble you should save often.4) In some areas in the game you can instantly die if you save there and load the save. Again, to avoid trouble you should save often.5) At some places you will have to pick some locks. Probably due to porting the game to PC, there is a glitch during lockpicking : you need Sam to be at maximum speed to be able to pick locks (scroll mouse wheel up).6) At some point, when selecting 'continue' in the main menu, the game said that no valid save files were found, but all I had to do was going to the 'load' section and saves were still here.All in all, you should avoid this game if you're not too patient, as it can be irritating to launch it 3 times in a row for it to randomly succeed and load correctly.

												I really wanted to like this game.  The level designs and concepts were great.  But the huge number of bugs/glitches/annoyances managed to suck all the fun out of this game.  I regularly I had to do internet searches on how to get around various problems so that I could progress in the game.The game crashes frequently.  And the saves sometimes get into some sort of corrupted state so that you have no choice but find a previous save (if you have one) and replay parts of the game.And if the save system wasn't so bad, this could be tolerable.  But quick saves don't work at all (apparently related to what drive you have the game installed on).  So you have to do manual saves and the saves don't get any sort of name and just appear in an unnecessarily small window (can see 4 at a time) in a random order (not even by save date) -- a total pain if you need to find the 2nd or 3rd last save so that you can replay to work around a problem.And the final level was just a travesty.  The game crashed in so many places and saves got corrupted.  You work around all of that and then you finally difuse the bomb and then the game just freezes -- nothing.  You have to use task manager to shut down the game and restart yet again.  Then finally found out that you had to change screen resolution to 800x600 just before you completed the final task so that could see the final cutscene and progess to the bonus mission.I can't believe that a product ever got released like this and obviously received such little support from the developers.  I don't really care whether this was Steam's fault, the publisher's fault or the developer's fault.  But the result is that a potentially very engaging game has become an epic fail.
